translation.en: Whether live action or animated, the beasties of The Witcher universe
possess the power to scare us senseless.
translation.ko: 우릴 공포에 휩싸이게 하는 힘이 있습니다

translation.en: And that's because they come with a history.
Some have been nesting in our nightmares ever since humans came out of the cave.
translation.ko: 인간이 동굴에서 나온 이후로 우리의 악몽 속에 자리 잡은 괴수들이 있어요

translation.en: Yes, I, Geralt of Trivia, am back.
This time, to explore the dark mythological origins
translation.ko: 이번에 탐구할 어두운 신화 속 기원은

translation.en: of the monsters in The Witcher Nightmare of the Wolf.
translation.ko: '위쳐: 늑대의 악몽'에 등장한 괴물들에 관한 겁니다

translation.en: So get ready, monster hunters.
Give a light to your witcher
Leave a comment for your witcher
It's monster mythology
We already covered the dangerous, vindictive woodland trickster spirit
translation.ko: 지난 동물 사전에서 이 위험하고 앙심을 품은 숲속 사기꾼 혼령 레쉬를 이미 다뤘으니

translation.en: called the Leshy in a previous bestiary,
translation.ko: 숲속 사기꾼 혼령 레쉬를 이미 다뤘으니

translation.en: so we'll leave you with this haiku about it,
translation.ko: 레쉬에 관한 설명은 짧은 시로 대신하죠

translation.en: played on top of spooky forest imagery.
In Slavic forests,
the beast shifts from tree to wolf.
Blood rains upon dried leaves.
translation.ko: 마른 나뭇잎 위로 피가 뚝뚝 떨어진다

translation.en: Don't make me say it again.
Don't mess with trees, y'all.
We all know the importance of a good night's sleep,
translation.ko: "명칭: 메어, 기원: 스칸디나비아 독일, 폴란드, 서식지: 미상" 숙면의 중요성은 누구나 알기에

translation.en: which makes a monster that stalks your sleep so very frightening.
translation.ko: 못 자게 괴롭히는 괴물이 무척 공포스러운 거죠

translation.en: Such was the mahr,
a demonic entity that squatted on a person's chest while they slept,
translation.ko: 이 사악한 괴수는 자는 사람의 가슴에 쭈그리고 앉아

translation.en: causing horrifying dreams.
Despite its name, the mahr was not a horse,
but rather resembled a kind of goblin.
They were, in fact, known to give horses bad dreams too.
Accounts of mahr visitations were widespread throughout Europe,
translation.ko: 메어가 목격된 사례는 유럽 전역에 퍼져있습니다

translation.en: from the German mahr to the Norwegian maritt.
Indeed, one famous Norse saga tells of a mahr that crushed a king's head.
translation.ko: 유명한 북유럽 전설에선 메어가 왕의 머리를 쳤다죠

translation.en: But read deeper and you find that his wife took out the hit.
translation.ko: 그러나 실은 왕의 아내가 메어에게 사주한 거였어요

translation.en: Yes, mahrs could be hired through conjurers and witches.
translation.ko: 네, 메어는 마술사와 마녀가 고용하기도 했습니다

translation.en: Mahrs could shrink down to fit inside keyholes,
translation.ko: 메어는 몸집을 작게 해 열쇠 구멍에 들어가기도 해서

translation.en: so one defense was to just stop those openings up.
translation.ko: 그 구멍을 막기만 해도 메어를 막을 수 있었죠

translation.en: Perhaps a less logical defense against mahr intrusion
was to pee in a bottle,
keep it for three days, and then throw it in a stream.
translation.ko: 3일 동안 갖고 있다가 개울에 안 버려도 된다고요

translation.en: Yeah, sure.
You do you.
Modern researchers believe that the proliferation of mahr folklore
translation.ko: 현대 연구자들은 메어에 관한 구전이 성행한 건

translation.en: was an attempt to explain the very real phenomenon of sleep paralysis,
translation.ko: 최대 20%의 인구가 실제로 겪는 수면 마비 증상을

translation.en: which affects up to 20% of humans.
They can think that, but I'm going to stop up my keyhole
translation.ko: 아무리 그렇다 해도 전 우리 집 열쇠 구멍 막고

translation.en: and pee in a jar anyway.
Sleep well, my friends.
Death should be a time for peace and quiet,
translation.ko: 죽음은 자고로 평안과 고요를 얻는 시간이죠

translation.en: so perhaps we can understand
why the undead, doomed-to-float-the-earth-forever wraith
translation.ko: 죽어서도 죽지 못하고 구천을 떠돌아야 하는 망령이

translation.en: is so darn malevolent.
It's a spectral being, the Scottish cousin of the ghost.
translation.ko: 망령은 분광 같은 존재로 유령의 스코틀랜드 사촌 격인데

translation.en: And like all Scottish cousins,
it's just a wee bit more trouble than its relatives.
translation.ko: 망령 역시 유령보다 사고를 더 치고 다녀요

translation.en: Accounts of how wraiths form differ,
but a Scottish minister in 1691 wrote poetically
that wraiths were the last breath exhaled by a person on the verge of death.
translation.ko: 망령은 죽음을 앞둔 사람이 내뱉는 마지막 숨이라고 했죠

translation.en: But everyone agrees they weren't happy creatures.
translation.ko: 그러나 망령이 유쾌하지 않은 건 모두 공감합니다

translation.en: Even the wraith's name speaks to its deep torment.
Etymologists have traced it to the Middle English version of "writhe,"
translation.ko: 어원학자들은 그 유래를 '라이드'의 중세 영어에서 찾았죠

translation.en: connecting it to "wreaths" and "wrath,"
twisted things and emotions, respectively.
They weren't just physically dangerous. They were harbingers of doom.
translation.ko: 망령은 그 실체도 위험했지만 죽음의 전령이기도 했어요

translation.en: According to Scottish folklore,
just seeing a wraith in the afternoon or evening
signified that death would come for the viewer within a year.
Wraiths eventually became associated with evil water spirits too.
translation.ko: 나중에는 사악한 물의 혼령으로 생각되기도 했습니다

translation.en: Scotland's water wraiths were lanky, female humanoids
translation.ko: 스코틀랜드 물의 망령은 가늘고 긴 여성의 형체를 띠고

translation.en: who lured drunken travelers into a watery grave.
translation.ko: 술 취한 여행자들을 꾀어 물속 무덤으로 데려갔답니다

translation.en: But in conclusion,
maybe don't go to Scotland.
Certainly don't drop dead there.
At least not until this whole wraith thing blows over.
translation.ko: 이 망령이란 게 없어질 때까지 "명칭: 늑대 인간 기원: 그리스 신화"

translation.en: Aside from dragons, the human-wolf hybrid
is one of the oldest continuously used monsters that we have in Western culture.
translation.ko: 서구 문화에서 가장 오래 지속적으로 소비되는 괴물입니다

translation.en: Most agree that the first reference to a werewolf is in The Epic of Gilgamesh,
translation.ko: 늑대 인간이 최초로 언급된 건 '길가메시 서사시'라는 데 대부분 동의하죠

translation.en: literally the first piece of Western prose in existence.
In it, Gilgamesh rejects a woman who turned her last man into a wolf.
translation.ko: 거기서 길가메시가 한 여인을 거부했는데 전 연인을 늑대로 만들어버린 여인이었다죠

translation.en: Probably a good call.
But the Greeks took werewolves to a new level.
translation.ko: 그리스 신화에선 늑대 인간이 훨씬 무섭게 나와요

translation.en: Most famously, the king Lycaon angered Zeus
translation.ko: 리카온 왕이 제우스를 노하게 한 이야기가 유명한데

translation.en: by serving him a meal made of… a little boy.
translation.ko: 제우스에게 대접한 요리가 남자아이로 만든 거였다죠

translation.en: Yikes.
Zeus struck back, turning the king and his sons
translation.ko: 이에 분노한 제우스가 왕과 그 아들들을 벌하여

translation.en: into ravenous wolves as punishment.
And cannibalism leading to a wolven curse
translation.ko: 식인 행위가 늑대의 저주로 연결되는 건

translation.en: is sort of a running theme in the Greek tales.
But in the Middle Ages, werewolves were no longer kings and princes.
translation.ko: 그러나 중세의 늑대 인간은 더는 왕과 왕자가 아닙니다

translation.en: They were everywhere, common folk, and there are records of them.
translation.ko: 평민과 섞여 도처에 있었고 그에 대한 기록도 있어요

translation.en: Gilles Garnier, for instance, the Werewolf of Dole,
translation.ko: 예를 들어 질 가르니에는 돌의 늑대 인간이라 불리는데

translation.en: burned at the stake for killing and eating children,
translation.ko: 아이들을 죽여서 먹은 죄로 화형에 처해졌습니다

translation.en: burning being one of the few ways to kill a werewolf.
translation.ko: 불은 늑대 인간을 죽이는 몇 안 되는 방법 중 하나죠

translation.en: The individuals accused may have actually been serial killers,
translation.ko: 늑대 인간이라 불린 이들은 사실 연쇄 살인범이었겠으나

translation.en: but it's likely that others were the victims of werewolf hysteria.
translation.ko: 늑대 인간에 대한 집단 공포로 죽은 사람도 있을 겁니다

translation.en: Given the werewolf's long history and vast spread,
translation.ko: 늑대 인간의 오랜 역사와 방대한 분포로

translation.en: it's no surprise that the trigger for wolven transformation has varied.
translation.ko: 늑대 인간으로 변하게 하는 요인에 관한 설도 다양한데요

translation.en: Of course, you probably know about a full moon,
but magic belts, pelts, and ointments enchanted by the devil
translation.ko: 마법 벨트, 생가죽 악령이 씌운 연고 역시

translation.en: have, at some point, served to spark the change.
translation.ko: 신체 변형을 일으키는 기폭제 역할을 합니다

translation.en: But maybe most surprising,
there may be a kernel of truth in this monster myth.
translation.ko: 이 괴물의 신화가 진실에 기반했을 수 있단 거죠

translation.en: An extremely rare condition called hypertrichosis,
translation.ko: '늑대 인간 신드롬'이라고도 하는 다모증이 있는 사람은

translation.en: AKA werewolf syndrome,
causes excess hair growth that looks pretty lupine.
translation.ko: 털이 과하게 자라 꼭 늑대처럼 보이기도 합니다

translation.en: So if you do see a werewolf, show some respect.
translation.ko: 그러니 늑대 인간을 본다면 정중하게 대하세요

translation.en: They are, after all, very old.
Wherever humans die, so everywhere,
translation.ko: "명칭: 언데드, 기원: 아이티 서식지: 묘소" 사람이 죽는 곳 어디든 즉, 온 세상에

translation.en: there are undead monsters.
In Arabia, we've seen the traveler-hunting ghoul.
In Scandinavia, the size-shifting draugr.
Although it didn't appear in Western literature until the 1800s,
it's thought that the word "zombie" originated in a few West African languages
translation.ko: '좀비'라는 단어의 기원이 서부 아프리카어에 있다고 생각됩니다

translation.en: that migrated to Haiti via enslaved African people.
translation.ko: 노예로 아이티에 끌려온 아프리카인이 전파한 거죠

translation.en: But according to the original Haitian folklore,
zombies weren't savage, flesh-eating monsters.
They were pitiful, mindless, captive beings
created from corpses by a bocor, an unfriendly neighborhood witch doctor,
translation.ko: 불친절한 이웃 주술 의사인 '보코어'가 시체를 갖고 만들어

translation.en: and used as free labor.
They represented eternal slavery
to a people that had endured and cast off
some of the most notoriously brutal conditions that slavery ever created.
Weirdly enough, a 1983 study found that a bocor
translation.ko: 기이하게도 1983년 연구 결과 보코어는 복어, 두꺼비독 환각제를 섞어 만든 혼합물로

translation.en: using a concoction made of puffer fish, and toad venoms and hallucinogens
translation.ko: 보코어는 복어, 두꺼비독 환각제를 섞어 만든 혼합물로

translation.en: could place a person into a zombie-like trance,
translation.ko: 사람을 좀비 같은 가수면 상태에 빠지게 할 수 있었죠

translation.en: and I think that combination would probably kill me.
translation.ko: 제게 그 혼합물을 먹였다면 전 아마 죽었을 테지만

translation.en: But the study is controversial.
Throughout the 1960s,
creators took the mindlessness of Haitian zombies
translation.ko: 창작자들은 자유 의지가 없는 이 아이티 좀비에게

translation.en: and added the ferocity of some other undead creatures.
Don't get me wrong, flesh-eating zombies are amazing,
but it's worth remembering that the original zombie had an even darker past.
translation.ko: 그러나 원조 좀비에게 더 어두운 과거가 있단 걸 기억하는 것도 좋겠죠

translation.en: Japan,
a land of extremes.
On one hand,
they unleashed a grime-licking bathtub monster
on the unsuspecting world,
and on the other hand,
they have super adorable fox spirits.
Yes, if you're somewhat familiar with Japanese,
you may have noticed that Kitsu from Nightmare of the Wolf
sounds remarkably similar to "kitsune,"
the Japanese word for both mundane and monstrous foxes.
translation.ko: 일본어로 속세의 무시무시한 여우를 일컫는 말이죠

translation.en: Oh, yeah, and also that she changes into a fox halfway through.
translation.ko: 맞아요, 실제로 영화에서 여우로 변하기도 합니다

translation.en: Whatever.
So, it's likely that Kitsu was inspired by the kawaii kitsune,
translation.ko: 따라서 킷수의 영감이 된 건 '카와이 키츠네'라고 보여져요

translation.en: a fox-like trickster spirit that populated the forests of Northeast Asia
translation.ko: 이 여우 같은 사기꾼 혼령은 여러 이름으로 불리며

translation.en: under a variety of names.
In traditional trickster fashion, they were sometimes benevolent.
translation.ko: 전통적인 사기꾼 기질로 때로 자애롭다고 알려졌어요

translation.en: Celestial messengers even.
Of course, they were just as likely
translation.ko: 그러나 그저 교활하게 형상을 바꾸며 환영을 이용해

translation.en: to use cunning, shape-shifting, and illusion to rattle their victims' minds,
translation.ko: 그러나 그저 교활하게 형상을 바꾸며 환영을 이용해 피해자의 생각을 조작했던 걸 겁니다

translation.en: particularly if those victims were wicked, greedy or drunk.
translation.ko: 특히 그 피해자가 사악하거나 욕심 많고 술에 취했다면요

translation.en: We can be whatever we imagine here, Vesemir. We can be rich.
translation.ko: 여기서 우린 뭐든지 될 수 있어 부자가 되는 거야

translation.en: Together, here,
translation.ko: 나와 함께 이 안에서 시간은 무의미해

translation.en: time is nothing.
Out there, I can save her.
That's worth more.
Now, out of my head.
Much like Bugs Bunny,
the kitsune particularly relish changing into a beautiful woman
in order to seduce unsuspecting men, sometimes even marrying them.
translation.ko: 잘 속는 남자들을 유혹하고 결혼까지 하기도 하죠

translation.en: Even today in Chinese culture, the word for fox spirit, "húli jīng"
translation.ko: 지금도 중국 문화에선 여우 정령을 일컫는 '후리징'이

translation.en: is commonly used to call someone a homewrecker.
translation.ko: 가정을 파탄 내는 사람을 부르는 말로 쓰입니다

translation.en: Look, I'm not saying I have a thing
for anthropomorphic animals that dress up like women,
translation.ko: 인간화가 가능한 동물을 좋아한단 건 아니지만

translation.en: but would I rather meet one instead of a bathtub monster?
translation.ko: 욕조 괴물을 만나느니 그런 동물을 만나겠냐고요?

translation.en: Yes, I would.
You can tell how much ancient humans feared being eaten from their monsters.
translation.ko: "명칭: 만티코어 기원: 페르시아 신화" "서식지: 산, 삼림" 고대인들은 괴물에 먹히는 게 두려웠음을 알 수 있어요

translation.en: Take the fearsome manticore,
a derivation of the old Persian word for "man-eater."
This monstrous hybrid typically mashed up the head of a human,
translation.ko: 이 괴물 같은 혼종은 전형적으로 인간의 머리와

translation.en: the body of a lion, and the tail of a scorpion.
translation.ko: 사자의 몸, 전갈의 꼬리가 합쳐진 형태인데

translation.en: Although modern variants sometimes add a pair of leathery wings too.
translation.ko: 현대에 와선 깃털이 무성한 두 날개가 붙여진 것도 있죠

translation.en: As if a scorpion's tail isn't bad enough,
the manticore could shoot theirs, like arrows.
And to complete the ferocious look,
the beast was said to have been colored blood-red.
Strangely, the sources say it had a voice like a melody played on pipes,
translation.ko: 또한 만티코어의 목소리는 파이프로 연주한 멜로디 같았다죠

translation.en: sort of like mine.
Oh, here he comes It's a manticore
Always violent and feral,
it's said to prefer a buffet of humans over just one,
and it ate them whole.
It became particularly evil in the Middle Ages
when everything became associated with the devil anyway.
translation.ko: 그땐 모든 걸 악마와 연결시켰던 때죠

translation.en: But scholars think the manticore may have been a stand-in for a real man-eater,
translation.ko: 그러나 학자들은 만티코어가 실존 식인 동물을 나타낸 걸 수도 있다고 봅니다

translation.en: the Caspian tiger, whose fur could look red in the sun.
translation.ko: 태양처럼 붉게 보이는 털을 가진 카스피 호랑이요

translation.en: Monsters are like anything else,
translation.ko: "명칭: 그리핀, 기원: 그리스 신화 서식지: 산, 동굴" 괴물도 마찬가지로

translation.en: they have their ups and downs in popular opinion.
And there's no better example than the griffin,
which has an abnormally long history.
translation.ko: 말도 안 되게 긴 역사가 있어요

translation.en: The first record we have dates back to 3000 B.C. in Persia,
although they truly flourished in ancient Greece.
translation.ko: 사실 그리핀이 많았던 곳은 고대 그리스입니다

translation.en: With the body of a lion, and the wings and head of an eagle,
translation.ko: 사자의 몸과 독수리의 날개 및 머리를 가졌죠

translation.en: thought to be two of nature's noblest creatures,
translation.ko: 자연의 가장 고결하다는 두 짐승이 합쳐져

translation.en: the griffin has, at times, enjoyed an association with royalty.
translation.ko: 그리핀은 한때 귀족과 같은 대우를 받았습니다

translation.en: You could often find their statues guarding tombs.
translation.ko: 그리핀 조각상을 세워 묘소를 지키게 하기도 했죠

translation.en: The beast was known to dig up gold
and, oddly for monsters, we know a little bit about its family life.
translation.ko: 괴물로는 특이하게도 그 가족에 대한 얘기가 있는데

translation.en: Griffins mated for life.
In the Middle Ages, though, griffins seemed slightly less helpful,
translation.ko: 중세에 그려진 그리핀은 살짝 덜 우호적이고

translation.en: slash slightly more bloodthirsty.
They were often depicted battling knights,
or even carrying them and their horses to their nests
for their little grifflings to snack upon.
In fact, horses, of all things, were their mortal enemies,
translation.ko: 사실 다른 무엇보다 말이 그들의 정적이었다는데

translation.en: which seems an unfair fight to me.
RIP, Roach.
